item.title: Downing Street party: No 10 staff joked about party amid lockdown restrictions
item.description: The video obtained by ITV comes after days of questions about the event that took place last year.

item.title: Covid: Early signs Omicron spreads more easily, says No 10
item.description: But PM's spokesman says exact impact is yet to be determined, as UK cases of the variant reach 437.

item.title: Sturgeon warns of 'rapid' rise in Omicron cases
item.description: Scotland's Covid restrictions to be reviewed daily as first minister warns that Omicron is a "significant challenge".

item.title: Afghanistan: Top UK official regrets holiday as country fell to Taliban
item.description: Sir Philip Barton says he has "reflected on" his 17-day summer holiday and would not do the same again.

item.title: Storm Barra: Weather warnings for most of UK as gales and snow hit
item.description: Most of the UK is covered by a yellow weather warning, with wind gusts exceeding 80mph in Wales.

item.title: Covid: Omicron appears more transmissible and medics test positive after party
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Tuesday evening.

item.title: Grenfell Tower inquiry: Government apologises to victims
item.description: The government admits a series of failings in the years leading up to the Grenfell Tower disaster.

item.title: Jamal Khashoggi: Suspect in murder of journalist arrested in Paris
item.description: French media say Khaled Aedh Alotaibi was arrested at Charles-de-Gaulle airport on Tuesday.

item.title: Sam and Chris Gould: Failures made after twins reported sex abuse
item.description: Sam and Chris Gould's parents say the family had been "left in limbo" before the girls' suicides.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell: Jury sees never-before-seen photos of Epstein and defendant
item.description: FBI agents submit previously unseen photo evidence as third accuser testifies in Maxwell trial.

item.title: Amazon services down for thousands of users
item.description: Customers of the e-commerce giant report problems with shopping services, Prime Video and Alexa.

item.title: Archers addict Camilla hosts 70th anniversary reception
item.description: Camilla admits she gets "quite ratty" if disturbed while listening to The Archers.

item.title: Ubisoft NFTs, called 'Digits', launch for in-game items
item.description: Game maker Ubisoft is launching its in-game NFT system this week.

item.title: Covid testing: New PCR rules throw plans into disarray
item.description: Travellers explain how their plans have been disrupted by the new rules for people arriving in the UK.

item.title: Mixed-race family suffered years of racist abuse from neighbours
item.description: A family was forced to move from their home, schools and jobs by their neighbours' harassment.

item.title: Edinburgh Zoo's giant pandas to stay another two years
item.description: It was thought Yang Guang and Tian Tian would have to return to China because of financial pressures.

item.title: Christmas dinner costs rise as inflation bites
item.description: Turkeys, sprouts and Christmas puddings are more expensive this year, research suggests.

item.title: Hollywood legend Mel Brooks' autobiography published
item.description: Hollywood legend Mel Brooks discusses love, life and bad taste as his autobiography is published.

item.title: Indonesia volcano: BBC reporter surrounded by houses buried in ash
item.description: Watch Valdya Baraputri in Indonesia describe the path of destruction from Mount Semeru's eruption.

item.title: The Scot trekking across Canada to help restore Highland forests
item.description: Michael Yellowlees and his Alaskan husky Luna spent nine months travelling coast-to-coast on foot.

item.title: Ros Atkins on... the No 10 Christmas party denials
item.description: Watch as Ros Atkins investigates the gap between government assurances and available evidence.

item.title: Mahbouba Seraj: Afghanistan is a country in trouble
item.description: Mahbouba Seraj is a prominent Afghan women’s rights activist. She has a personal message for the Taliban.

item.title: Hong Kong Covid: The Cathay pilots stuck in 'perpetual quarantine'
item.description: One Cathay Pacific pilot said he had spent almost 150 days in quarantine this year alone.

item.title: Why I celebrated my 40th birthday with 29 hours of spin
item.description: Jackie Scully thought she wouldn't reach the age of 40, but did - marking the day with a feat of endurance.

item.title: The Palestinian jailbreak that rocked Israel
item.description: The search for six Palestinian fugitives from an Israeli prison unearths a story of dispossession, violence and bitter division in a fractured region.

item.title: James Webb Space Telescope scientist: 'It's the future of astrophysics'
item.description: The James Webb Space Telescope is expected to be 100 times more powerful than the Hubble.

item.title: BBC 100 Women 2021: Who is on the list this year?
item.description: Our most inspiring and influential women of 2021 and how they're making a difference in the world.

item.title: 'I had to move across America when I became allergic to the sun'
item.description: After experiencing an unusual allergic reaction, Carrie moves across America to escape the sun.

item.title: Quarantine hotels: Returning Brits struggle to book
item.description: Some UK residents coming back from South Africa are still struggling to find quarantine hotel rooms.

item.title: Afghanistan: How many people has the UK evacuated?
item.description: The UK government has defended the evacuation from Kabul in August, after criticism from a whistleblower.

item.title: Ashes: England in Australia - all you need to know about the 2021-22 series
item.description: BBC Sport's guide to all you need to know about the 2021-22 Ashes between England and Australia.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Why our black and South Asian friends and family still won't have a jab
item.description: Some black and South Asian people say conversations about the vaccine are "frustrating" and "tense".

item.title: Landscapers: The surreal suburban murders behind a TV drama
item.description: The quietly bizarre murder story has been reimagined into a drama starring Olivia Colman.

item.title: Juan Jose Florian: Colombia's Para-cycling 'superhero' and his dramatic life story
item.description: Juan Jose Florian was forced into armed conflict on the opposite side to family. When a bomb nearly killed him, sport helped heal.

item.title: Amalia: Heir to the Dutch throne keeps it normal at 18
item.description: Princess Amalia had an ordinary childhood and wants her life to continue that way.

item.title: Omicron: Why is Nigeria on the travel red list?
item.description: The UK has placed travel restrictions on arrivals from Nigeria and several other African countries - are they fair?

item.title: Lara Croft: 25 years of Tomb Raider and a British gaming icon
item.description: The team behind Lara Croft talk to Newsbeat about her history and where she goes next.

item.title: Care homes: Following the money trail
item.description: BBC Panorama unpicks the financial webs behind leading companies, as families ask where their fees go.

item.title: Wet Leg, Pink Pantheress and Central Cee make BBC Sound of 2022 list
item.description: They're among 10 acts tipped for success in the annual BBC list, previously won by Adele and Celeste.

item.title: AC Milan 1-2 Liverpool: Reds beat Milan for perfect group stage record
item.description: Liverpool come from behind to beat AC Milan and finish the Champions League group stage with six wins from six.

item.title: Man City finish group stage with RB Leipzig defeat as Walker sent off
item.description: Kyle Walker is sent off as Manchester City end their Champions League group campaign with defeat by RB Leipzig in a match played without fans because of Covid-19 restrictions.

item.title: In-play clips, highlights and ball-by-ball commentary - follow the Ashes on the BBC
item.description: BBC Sport will bring you live radio, text and in-play highlights of the men's Ashes this winter.

item.title: Fury ordered to defend title against fellow Briton Whyte
item.description: Tyson Fury is ordered to defend his heavyweight title against British rival Dillian Whyte by the World Boxing Council.

item.title: Olesen 'embarrassed and felt horrible' after sexual assault claim
item.description: Ryder Cup winner Thorbjorn Olesen says he was "embarrassed and felt horrible" after being accused of drunkenly sexually assaulting a woman on a British Airways flight in 2019.

item.title: Mbappe earns record & Messi scores twice in PSG win over Bruges
item.description: Kylian Mbappe becomes the youngest player to reach 30 Champions League goals as Paris St-Germain round off Group A with a win.

item.title: Malala’s message to an Afghan schoolgirl
item.description: Nobel laureate Malala Yousafzai exchanges letters with Rohila, whose education is now on hold.

item.title: Rebel Wilson on weight loss: I know what it’s like to be invisible
item.description: The actress, producer and director opens up about her weight loss, in an exclusive BBC interview.

item.title: 'I am an Afghan public prosecutor but I can't do the job I love'
item.description: Afghan public prosecutor Masouma, now in hiding, writes to British barrister Helena Kennedy QC.

item.title: Helping trans people escape death in their home countries
item.description: Iman Le Caire made it her mission to help other trans people flee persecution in hostile countries.

item.title: The women publicly tortured after being accused of sorcery
item.description: Monica fled her home in Papua New Guinea after being accused of killing her father with witchcraft.

item.title: 'Play football in the depths of your mind, if only for now'
item.description: US soccer star Megan Rapinoe writes to a young Afghan footballer who cannot play under the Taliban.

item.title: Covid passports: How do I get one and when will I need it?
item.description: Scotland has expanded its passport scheme to include negative test results.

item.title: Omicron: What Covid tests do I need if I travel abroad?
item.description: There are now pre- and post-arrival tests for travellers to the UK.

item.title: What are the Covid variants and will vaccines still work?
item.description: A new Covid variant has emerged that looks worryingly different to the one vaccines were designed to fight.

item.title: Covid: Who can have a booster jab and how can you get one?
item.description: All UK adults will be offered a Covid booster, and 12-15-year-olds will be offered a second jab.

item.title: Covid: What are the social distancing rules across the UK?
item.description: Some companies are cancelling Christmas parties over Omicron fears, but what do the rules say?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Coronavirus treatments: What progress is being made?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.

item.title: Omicron: How do you detect it?
item.description: Swabs from PCR tests can help identify omicron, but genetic analysis is needed to confirm it.

item.title: Is Omicron more harmful than other Covid variants? And other questions
item.description: Covid rules have been strengthened in response to concern over the newly-identified Omicron variant.

item.title: Omicron: How are Covid rules changing in the UK?
item.description: Covid rules are being strengthened in response to the Omicron variant

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people are vaccinated in the UK?
item.description: A look at the progress made in vaccinating the country's population, as more than 51 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: New Omicron variant: Are low vaccination rates in South Africa a factor?
item.description: Has the slow rollout of vaccines in southern Africa allowed coronavirus mutations to develop?

item.title: Omicron: What are England's mask rules now?
item.description: Face coverings are a legal requirement again in England in shops and on public transport.

item.title: Omicron: How are pupils being kept Covid-safe?
item.description: Secondary pupils in England and Wales are being asked to start wearing masks in school again.

item.title: Omicron: Do travel bans work against new Covid variants?
item.description: Is there evidence that travel restrictions help stop the spread of coronavirus?

item.title: Covid vaccine: Can US troops be punished for refusing the jabs?
item.description: The US military has said that America's 2.1 million soldiers and sailors must all get the vaccine.

item.title: ‘It’s like hell in here’: The struggle to save Afghanistan's starving babies
item.description: Doctors in Afghanistan’s crisis-hit hospitals are caring for their patients in almost impossible conditions.

item.title: Stanley Menzo: Ajax's former goalkeeper on dealing with racism in Dutch game
item.description: Stanley Menzo would encounter racism almost every week on the football pitch. When a young man abused him to his face, he struck back.

item.title: Migrant crisis: The Channel beaches that host a lethal trade in human hope
item.description: The journeys migrants make across the Channel are book-ended with beaches that tell the story of the crisis.

item.title: The ‘cocaine collectors’ retrieving smuggled drugs in Rotterdam
item.description: Young criminals are risking their lives to retrieve drugs smuggled into the Netherlands amongst freight arriving from Latin America.
